trial_identification.studytitle: To facilitate the implementation of the NHMRC Clinical practice guidelines for the psychosocial care of adults with cancer
trial_identification.scientifictitle: To improve clinician's skills of assessing the supportive care needs of adult cancer patients by providing communication workshops, patient assessment tools and clinical supervision.

conditions.healthcondition: Clinicians providing care to cancer patients.

interventions.interventions: This 12 month qualitative action research study uses a cyclic process to implement change in clinical practice. There are no control groups. The interventions are determined by a systematic problem-solving approach to identify barriers to change and implement actions to overcome barriers. Intervention strategies have included a 2 day communication skills workshop, the use of a Supportive Care Needs Screening Tool in routine clinical practice, the documentation of resources in a guide, and participating in supervision of clinical practice for three months.

primaryOutcome.outcome: First primary outcome is participant's self report that they systematically identify psychosocial needs in clinical practice.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: This will be self reported through a study specific survey four months post workshop.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Second primary outcome is participants' skills in communication which will be identified by participants
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Through self critique at one and four months post workshop.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Third primary outcome will be frequency of use by participants of the Supportive Needs Screening Tool in practice.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Reported by clinicians at four months post workshop.

primaryOutcome.outcome: The fourth primary outcome is the publication of an effective supportive care guideline and referral resource for the clinical setting for all participants.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: This will be made available by the end of four months post workshop.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Secondary outcome will be participant satisfaction with the workshop measured immediately post workshop by a particpant completed questionnaire.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Participants must be involved in the provision of cancer care to adult patients; participants must be involved as part of their clinical practice assessment of cancer patients; participants must be from participating agencies are the Western and Central ICS, the Loddon Mallee RICS and the Hume RICS.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Participants not willing to participate in the two day workshop; paticipants not nominated by their organisation.

ethicsAndSummary.summary: It is proposed to test the refinement and dissemination of the C-CARE model of psychosocial assessment more broadly across the tumour streams at Peter Mac in the first instance and then to further refine the model in the Western and Central ICS (W&CICS) and in two Regional Integrated Cancer Services. The impetus for this project is two fold: the publication of the NHMRC Clinical Practice Guidelines for the Psychosocial Care of Adults with Cancer (NBCC & NCCI 2003) and the prioritization of psychosocial assessment within the Victorian Cancer Services Improvement Program. Funding for this project has been provided by the Department of Human Services.
